body:
This PR aims to fix two possible root causes of GeyserMC#2540.

1. When teleporting, the player's stored position is updated, but due to latency, the player will send 1-2 packets with the old position.
2. `isValidMove` does not check packets that are not `Mode.NORMAL`. 

I also converted `getPlayerCollidableBlocks` into an iterator to prevent big ArrayLists from being created.

The first 2 commits are for Java plugin channel tracking.  
listen to `minecraft:register` and `minecraft:unregister`
  
**2nd part is more interesting**  
I'm the developer of a Java Emote mod, [EmoteCraft](https://github.com/KosmX/emotes)  
And I want it to work with Geyser and Bedrock.  
Geyser did not send emote information to Java server, I want to fix that with this PR.  

My fork does send the emote to the Java server __if__ the server is listening to `geyser:emote` channel.  
If the server does not do that, Geyser will just send the emote to other geyser players. (as it does now).

comments: I consider this pr done, if any more things need to be changed please let me know. I've tested it multiple times on various servers/forks.

The only code that we reasonable need from mclogs-java is [this method](https://github.com/aternosorg/mclogs-java/blob/master/src/main/java/gs/mclo/java/MclogsAPI.java#L28-L50)

And I'm not sure why both mclogs-java and mclogs both censor addresses, but they do, so we don't have to worry about doing it
Isn’t it like a big privacy invasion to upload a users private logs to a public host probably without their knowledge?
Logs will not be uploaded unless they are specified as a command option in our dump command.

> Logs will not be uploaded unless they are specified as a command option in our dump command.

So some new user comes to the discord for help and someone tells them run this command, and boom, all your data is uploaded to a public host?

The site we upload logs to censors out IPs which, in my opinion, is the only personally identifiable data in a log. Everything else is needed and would be asked for anyway already without this PR. If you have a concern about the way this will be integrated into our support processes, I recommend you head on over to https://github.com/GeyserMC/GeyserDiscordBot/pull/161 which is where the information will be presented from our bot.

Also, if anyone wants to review the information before uploading to dump.geysermc.org, they can include `offline` in the dump command arguments to create the information in a local file instead.

Data uploaded to dump.geysermc.org is publicly accessible, but dump IDs/links are only shared with the user running the command

> Also, if anyone wants to review the information before uploading to dump.geysermc.org, they can include `offline` in the dump command arguments to create the information in a local file instead.
> 
> 
> 
> Data uploaded to dump.geysermc.org is publicly accessible, but dump IDs/links are only shared with the user running the command

This PR isnt about uploading to dump.geysermc.org is it? its about uploading to mclo.gs, which is not under geyser control at all

> The site we upload logs to censors out IPs which, in my opinion, is the only personally identifiable data in a log. Everything else is needed and would be asked for anyway already without this PR. If you have a concern about the way this will be integrated into our support processes, I recommend you head on over to https://github.com/GeyserMC/GeyserDiscordBot/pull/161 which is where the information will be presented from our bot.

You can't account for plugins that leak other sensitive information, and in my opinion any blind uploading of logs like this is very bad, it just reeks of data leaks waiting to happen on a site that gives you no contol because its not under geysermc control.
RE the discord bot, that's not my main concern, my main concern is blind uploading of logs data which may include sensitive information to a host that to my knowledge doesn't allow deleting the logs

We can always change to our own log sharing system if needed, or you can suggest something to https://github.com/aternosorg/mclogs. The problem is, of course, that an uploading system with no account means you can't easily delete the data.

> You can't account for plugins that leak other sensitive information

As far as I know, any Java Edition-related support server will ask for complete logs, so this isn't a problem that is solely on us.

> my main concern is blind uploading of logs data which may include sensitive information

That is why I suggested looking at the PR - the `logsdump.tag` contains the file that will be shown to people when someone runs the `!!logsdump` command in our server to request logs.

You still mention sensitive data, but I've never seen personal data in logs ever being an issue, other than IP addresses (and like one complaint about UUIDs, but if we know your username we can find your UUID).

> RE the discord bot, that's not my main concern, my main concern is blind uploading of logs data which may include sensitive information to a host that to my knowledge doesn't allow deleting the logs

The logs are uploaded **only** if the user *specifies* it, so i don’t see the problem.

You have to tell it to upload the logs. Also, I believe Aternos to be a trustworthy company. I see no reason not to trust them, as i see no reason not to trust pastebin. There is no need for us to reinvent the wheel with everything when Aternos already provide a great service.
Also logs automatically delete after a certain period of time i believe, which is something you won’t get on most paste sites.

This PR fixes trapdoor collision and an issue that assigned some block state the wrong BlockCollision subclass.
This PR also reduces the number of stored BlockCollision instances.

I've marked this as a draft because I assume these changes will lead to more issues with concurrency. I would appreciate feedback regarding this.
I also plan on fixing ladder collision since ladders are now fully broken with these changes.

I've attached two registry dumps that list the block id, the java identifier, the assigned collision type, and the hash code of the bounding boxes.

[collisionsMaster.txt](https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/files/6894764/collisionsMaster.txt)
[collisionsPR.txt](https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/files/6894765/collisionsPR.txt)
comments: ~~davchoo for project lead~~

This should be ready for review & testing.
From my testing this should resolve GeyserMC#682 and the iron bars in the video of GeyserMC#1786.
Tested fine and didn't see any problems.
commit_messages:
Collision Registry (#2430)

* Fix trapdoor collision

* Add EqualsAndHashCode to all Collision subclasses and shift code around

EqualsAndHashCode are required on subclasses otherwise blocks will be assigned an incorrect collision instance. (Doors and trapdoors are mixed and ladder sometimes gets a DoorCollision instance).
Added protected constructor to BlockCollision to make boundingBoxes final.
Removed EmptyCollision because I don't think it is useful.
Moved conversion from ArrayNode to BoundingBoxes[] from OtherCollision to CollisionRegistryLoader
Removed regex from SnowCollision and use default bounding boxes.

* Deduplicate BlockCollision instances

* Create one set of bounding boxes for all BlockCollisions

* Don't depend on the player's block position in DoorCollision

* Fix dirt path position corrections

Grass paths were renamed to dirt path in 1.17
Fix position correction for y=1, y=2, y=255, and y=256

* Increase pushAwayTolerance depending on distance from origin

This should fix position corrections for blocks less than 1 unit in length/width at high coordinates.
This includes ladders after x 4096 or z 4096
Not too sure about the math here though

* Use ThreadLocal for position

Hopefully resolves concurrency issues

* Remove comment and add layer check to SnowCollision

body:
When building on IntelliJ, the annotation processors only process classes that were changed or rebuilt. The generated annotation files would then be incomplete or contain deleted classes. 
These changes should remedy this by loading the previously generated annotation lists.
commit_messages: Improve annotation processing (#2422)

body:
This PR introduces the concept of using Netty's LocalChannel - a channel type that performs the same network actions as a normal Minecraft connection, albeit locally in the Java runtime - in order to join the Java server without requiring a TCP connection. This introduces increased performance, always-correct IP addresses, and less configuration required (`remote` `address` and `remote` `port` are 99% irrelevant for plugin versions with this PR).

The code changes may cause plugin conflicts, but through testing any such problem has been solved.
commit_messages:
Connect Geyser players directly to the server for plugin versions (#2413)

- Faster loading times and improved latency; Geyser no longer creates a physical TCP connection to join the server
- Less configuration: remote address and port are now irrelevant
- Accurate IP addresses without needing Floodgate.

Co-authored-by: Redned <redned235@gmail.com>

body:
There are some situations where server owners - both those with and without Geyser - do not want Bedrock players to be able to godbridge/Bedrock scaffold [where people can place blocks in front of them without blocks being on the floor]. This PR implements a barrier to prevent this. *Do note* that this isn't a replacement for anticheat, and should instead be treated as a notification for genuine Bedrock clients that godbridging will not work.

This PR also implements the start of the GeyserSettings plugin, which will allow server owners with and without Geyser to control specific gameplay-related settings for incoming Bedrock clients.
comments: I know this PR is half a year old, but this feature is critically important on servers with modes that have a lot of bridging (e.g. Bedwars and Skywars). The insane advantage bedrock players have with this issue is so bad that, (for my server at least), a moderator basically has to watch over every match to ensure nobody abuses this “feature”. I feel as if merging this is a requirement for this very reason. Takes up a lot of staff’s time and also ruins the mode if no staff are online. Please, make sure this gets integrated with Geyser. body:
When requesting a skin, it opens a new thread. This could lead to there being too many threads open and the process not being able to open more of them. Then you'll get an error complaining about not being able to open threads.

This is the error which was causing the threads not to be closed (I think)
```[WARNING] [Geyser-BungeeCord] Failed getting skin for 46814159-5b0b-4136-bfbc-4deeb3463b72
java.lang.NullPointerException
    at org.geysermc.connector.skin.SkullSkinManager.lambda$requestAndHandleSkin$0(SkullSkinManager.java:62)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.uniWhenComplete(CompletableFuture.java:859)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$UniWhenComplete.tryFire(CompletableFuture.java:837)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Completion.exec(CompletableFuture.java:479)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinTask.doExec(ForkJoinTask.java:290)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool$WorkQueue.topLevelExec(ForkJoinPool.java:1020)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool.scan(ForkJoinPool.java:1656)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool.runWorker(ForkJoinPool.java:1594)
    at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinWorkerThread.run(ForkJoinWorkerThread.java:183)```
comments:
Thanks for the PR!

I don't think this is the correct solution here. Should this change be committed, the downloading of skull images will block the thread and prevent things like chunks from loading until the skin image is downloaded. Additionally, a dedicated executor service is reversed for skin downloading already: https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/master/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/skin/SkinProvider.java#L201

I do acknowledge something is fishy as SkinProvider#supplySkin should never return null.
Due to no response and my above explanation of the side effects of this PR, I am going to close this. If there is an update, I will be happy to reopen. Thanks!

body:
This is a major internal refactor to the way lots of data is stored within Geyser. Anything involving registering data has been moved into the `Registries` class, with the exception of all the block registration data being stored in `BlockRegistries`. Ultimately, this is to help centralize various registration data and create a more consistent system compared to what was done previously.

This PR does not add or remove any gameplay mechanics and does not fix any bugs; it's largely just a codebase refactor.

body: Correct spawn method and fix spawn twice when spigot processing item merge.
comments: Could you describe what bug this fixes and/or how to replicate this? Thanks!

If you look at the console log, you will find this error report.

1. when spawn item: 
Geyer send an AddEntityPacket(at Entity.spawnEntity) and an AddItemEntityPacket(at ItemEntity.updateBedrockMetadata) with same entity id.

2. when spigot do item merge
Geyser send two AddItemEntityPacket(at ItemEntity.updateBedrockMetadata)

Both of these behaviors will cause the client to report an error (but not damage the function)

I would definitely appreciate comments in the code explaining that. Additionally, I think the code would look cleaner if it looked something like https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/master/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/entity/WitherSkullEntity.java#L48 - we don't need to check for validity on entity metadata send; just despawn the old entity and create a new one right away.

> I would definitely appreciate comments in the code explaining that. Additionally, I think the code would look cleaner if it looked something like https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/master/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/entity/WitherSkullEntity.java#L48 - we don't need to check for validity on entity metadata send; just despawn the old entity and create a new one right away.

You're right. I'll update this PR soon.
The logic looks fine to me, but I won't be able to test this until Monday unless someone else does.
Thanks!

This PR doesn't fix the obvious problem, but right code is always good, isn't it?

comments: Yo, adding the news checker is cool and all but its really odd that its a web socket and not disableable. Whats the reasoning behind it using a web socket? (As a side note: This is the most confusing diff I have ever seen on. site, GitHub are you doing ok??)

> Yo, adding the news checker is cool and all but its really odd that its a web socket and not disableable. Whats the reasoning behind it using a web socket? (As a side note: This is the most confusing diff I have ever seen on. site, GitHub are you doing ok??)

Hi. The websocket part was made for the skin uploader. And because it is a websocket, I figured that I can also use it for pushing news (basically the update checker) when the news comes out.
The reason why I chose a websocket for the skin uploading is because it can take a while for a skin to upload (there is a queue) and one Geyser instance can be uploading quite a lot of skins.
There should probably be an option to disable skin uploading and checking news, yeah. I just forgot to make the config options.

body:
By updating these dependencies, we bring in a couple fixes that should improve network performance:

- Use TCP_NODELAY for the Java connection
- Use Epoll/KQueue if possible for the Java connection
- Only use one event loop for the Java connection
- Fix Netty dependencies so Spigot and BungeeCord can use native network types

Currently, Geyser-Spigot pre-1.12 breaks with these changes. It is unlikely that this will be fixed.

    Use TCP_NODELAY for the Java connection

    Only use one event loop for the Java connection
    Fix Netty dependencies so Spigot and BungeeCord can use native network types

Currently, Geyser-Spigot pre-1.12 breaks with these changes. It is unlikely that this will be fixed.

body:
Geyser now supports block picking for item frames. It checks to see if the item frame has an item in it - if so, it attempts the same block picking process with the item inside (NBT included). Otherwise, it attempts to pick for an item frame item.

This commit also improves item frames by having the internal map store the entity and not the ID - in many situations, this prevents two maps from having to be searched. Additionally, item frames are no longer despawned if an item is placed on them - rather, it waits until the server tells us to despawn the entity.
commit_messages:
Item frame optimization and block picking support (#2203)

Geyser now supports block picking for item frames. It checks to see if the item frame has an item in it - if so, it attempts the same block picking process with the item inside (NBT included). Otherwise, it attempts to pick for an item frame item.

This commit also improves item frames by having the internal map store the entity and not the ID - in many situations, this prevents two maps from having to be searched. Additionally, item frames are no longer despawned if an item is placed on them - rather, it waits until the server tells us to despawn the entity.

body:
For the InteractAt type of packet of the PlayerInteractEntityPacket, Java sends a diff between the entity's current position and the hit result of its cursor. Bedrock sends the full vector location in its interaction. Therefore, we just do the diff ourselves.

This fixes taking armor off of armor stands.
commit_messages:
Fix interact entity packet (#2179)

For the InteractAt type of packet of the PlayerInteractEntityPacket, Java sends a diff between the entity's current position and the hit result of its cursor. Bedrock sends the full vector location in its interaction. Therefore, we just do the diff ourselves.

This fixes taking armor off of armor stands.

I feel like there should be an option in the config file to be able to choose whether to block or allow bedrock players to be able to swap armor, for 2 reasons:
a) java clients could install some client sided mod to allow them to do this
b) bedrock players may want this functionality as it is something they are used to

This will not be a config option as Geyser does not modify the server at this time. I may develop a plugin that allows for this.

(This is not just a parity fix; it's a visual glitch. Bedrock thinks you switched but the server knows you didn't.)

body:
The server only started sending its render distance during 1.14. ViaVersion compensates by sending 64 as the render distance, always - but this can choke up Bedrock in various ways. This PR fixes two separate issues related:

- In some instances, the client would be stuck on Building Terrain during server switch. This is solved by fake-decreasing the render distance during server transfer. Zero issues have been found thus far.
- When switching servers, chunks could be dropped. While not pretty, if the client is not spawned, they are teleported to near the chunks so they cannot be unloaded.

body: I don't know if this can *only* occur when the server has block-adding mods, but I think completely failing to let players craft any items at all would qualify as "bad behavior". This PR filters items from the stonecutter recipe list which would otherwise trigger a NullPointerException, so only the invalid item will be uncraftable, not *all* items.
comments: If an invalid item is sent as a recipe, where does the NPE happen?

the line immediately after the check:
```java
data.getValue().sort(Comparator.comparing((stoneCuttingRecipeData ->
                    ItemRegistry.getItem(stoneCuttingRecipeData.getResult()).getJavaIdentifier())));
```
In my testing I believe I found that it could happen both on `ItemRegistry.getItem()` and on `.getJavaIdentifier()`. The ingredient null checks might not be necessary - They weren't for my case, at least.

I don't think a stream is necessary here (streams are generally regarded as not the best thing to use anyway). What I would do is, in the comparator lambda, save the result of the ItemEntry to a variable. if it's null, return `""`. Otherwise, return the Java identifier as normal. 
The `getJavaIdentifier()` should never be null.
then at:
```java
ItemData input = ItemTranslator.translateToBedrock(session, ingredient);
ItemData output = ItemTranslator.translateToBedrock(session, stoneCuttingData.getResult());
```
you can do a `if input.getId() == 0 { continue; }` if you want (and same for output).
I handled this in https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/commit/a5779a716bfb0d5cfd84eebaf41cd999bd56c021 and added you as a co-author. Thanks!

Fix item enchanting pre-1.14 (#2127)

If the server spams the window property update packet, then the network ID assigned for each enchanting slot will update too quickly, essentially disabling enchanting. This commit remedies this by only updating the network ID of each slot if a property changed.

body: In the config, you can set `actionbar-cooldown` to true so that the hit cooldown shows up in the actionbar instead of in the title.
comments: This fixes #1685
Can you merge master into this so your build can compile? :)

The concept looks fine to me, but we're internally discussing if we want this change merged with the current configuration option - this would break existing configs most likely though. Just letting you know so we're not just ignoring your PR!

I'm so sorry on keeping you waiting! Here's what I propose as a better alternative to two configuration options:
- keep everything under `show-cooldown`
- `false` still means no cooldown should be shown. `true` should redirect to `title`.
- `actionbar` as the input means that the actionbar should be used.

Does that sound good? Let me know if you need help!
@Camotoy, I have done what you requested, if you need anything else, I'm available to do it.
Looks like your mappings and languages submodules need to be updated!
How can I do that?

`git submodule update`
`git add connector/src/main/resources/mappings`
`git add connector/src/main/resources/languages`
`git commit -m "Update mappings"`

Should do the trick?
It says I'm up to date and that `connector/src/main/resources/languages` is untracked content
I don't understand, it refuses to update the mappings.
It's fixed! Though I'm not sure what I did to do so...

Do you think you could make an enum for each option so we don't have to compare a string each time? See https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/master/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/common/AuthType.java#L49 as an example of what I'm talking about.

Also, I meant that `show-cooldown`'s title option should literally be called `title` in the config and `true` should also equal title.
Thank you for your contribution, and thank you for being patient!

I don't know how widespread use this would get, but here it is if you want it.

If you wanted to give it a test run:

```bash
docker build -t geyser -f standalone.Dockerfile https://github.com/JamesTheAwesomeDude/Geyser.git
docker run -p 19132:19132/udp -v `pwd`/geyser:/var/lib/geyser geyser
```
comments:
On behalf of RTM, the person who knows Docker best among us developers:

> Hmm, honestly it would probs be better just using the ones in the pterodactyl repo, could you link that and suggest he uses that instead? If he has a decent reason to add it then I'll look over it better tomorrow

Said repository: https://github.com/GeyserMC/pterodactyl-stuff/tree/docker-geyser
~~I need to look at this better tomorrow but do these images not give you the same if not more functionality. They are designed for pterodactyl panel but should run on any system.~~

> ~I need to look at this better tomorrow but do these images not give you the same if not more functionality. They are designed for pterodactyl panel but should run on any system.~

I had not seen those before — though those are just a wrapper around a shell script that fetches CI artifacts at runtime; that Dockerfile:

- does not store code in the r/o `image`, doing which is one of the points of Docker
- does not compile from source during the `docker build` stage

Conversely, this PR contains something more like a mainstream Dockerfile in the vein of the official ones on the Hub.

I'm not familiar with the Pterodactyl Panel internal architecture, so I can't comment on the interactions between it and Docker or whether this would actually be better for that use-case in the long run.

This PR is unfortunately stale/outdated - hence i'll close this. Thanks anyways!
While not a direct dockerfile, there are official ptero eggs available to use, which might serve a similar purpose: <https://github.com/GeyserMC/pterodactyl-stuff/>.

body:
As Bedrock does not have world border support, this PR translates what the Java server sends us for a world border into particles and a message, while also preventing the Bedrock client from moving outside of the world border.
Thanks to both Luke and OFunny who started on this work.

Two things to note about this PR:

- ~~There is a mix-up between warning blocks and warning time that I have addressed with https://github.com/Steveice10/MCProtocolLib/pull/614.~~
- ~~OFunny added a lot of thread-safe precautions which I did not implement since things seem to work *fine*. I will ensure this PR gets tested to ensure there is no unwanted behavior from this.~~ Now irrelevant with every player guaranteed their own event loop for all packets.
comments: In addition to the particles, is there a way to allow the user to move out of the border, but they take damage by doing so?

@Comstepr as Java cannot do this, Bedrock can't either. If the border is shrinking, then Bedrock can escape the border, because Java can as well. Damage is controlled entirely serverside so there's nothing we can do about that.
commit_messages:
Add world border translation (#1839)

As Bedrock does not have world border support, this PR translates what the Java server sends us for a world border into particles and fog, while also preventing the Bedrock client from moving outside of the world border.

If a Java player attempts to use a Bedrock-only command, such as `geyser statistics`, they will get an error message stating that this command is only for Bedrock players.

This commit also cleans up Velocity Adventure dependency usage. Issues were caused because of the way relocation works and because Velocity also uses Adventure.

Can we use this feature and include other commands java players are not allowed to use?

For example I have a forms plugin, and I don't want java players issuing server commands to open forms as it would spam errors to my console.

Is there a way to not allow java players to use commands you want, or is this just for geyser based commands?
This is just for Geyser based commands. If you want to implement that yourself, I would recommend to check for a Floodgate player and return a similar message if one is not found.

body:
This adds Microsoft account authentication to Geyser.

Main authentication screen, now has the option to use a Mojang or Microsoft account:
![2021-01-05_20-57-50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5401186/103698077-ba0d7700-4f98-11eb-8938-6c9d2c94cdbd.png)

The submenu for Microsoft account sign in. (if `allow-password-authentication` is disabled in the config this is skipped)
![2021-01-05_20-57-57](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5401186/103698080-bb3ea400-4f98-11eb-902c-8245824a0995.png)

The code authentication screen, for easy non-password based login.
![2021-01-05_20-58-04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5401186/103698083-bc6fd100-4f98-11eb-96b4-a6abeb6f9e03.png)
comments:
My friend tried connecting and he got an email from Microsoft about a "malicious login" from my IP address.
This is because "Log in with username and password" sends account credentials over the internet, and has the geyser instance running on the server log in. Sending passwords over the internet is bad security practice, as a malicious or compromised operator will have access to account credentials. Therefore "Log in with username and password" should be removed.
Your password isn’t sent it’s just a token
If it were removed everyone with a Microsoft account would no longer be able to sign in, and also there's nothing malicious, if you don't believe me you can check yourself
Saying this should be removed is like saying crafting tables should be removed because they look ugly.
We don't really have an other choice. You have to login somehow.
If you don't want to sign in using the password, you can always login using the code.

> 
> 
> Your password isn’t sent it’s just a token

It does if you log in with username and password

> 
> 
> If it were removed everyone with a Microsoft account would no longer be able to sign in, and also there's nothing malicious, if you don't believe me you can check yourself

I trust geyser but still, you're sending credentials to an external server(as a player). That's what tokens are for. Also I'm talking about the insecure option, the secure one that uses tokens is fine.

> 
> 
> If you don't want to sign in using the password, you can always login using the code.

I agree, but logging in with username and password should still be removed since it's insecure.

> 
> 
> Saying this should be removed is like saying crafting tables should be removed because they look ugly.

I'm not sure if you understand, I'm talking about security not aestetics

Just to add the final touches to this conversation - if you are concerned about the security of username and password, Geyser currently has an option to disable the use of passwords when logging in with online mode. As Mojang accounts still require a password, and our saved logins system uses usernames and passwords, we will not be considering disabling this option globally until at least the migration from Mojang accounts to Microsoft accounts is complete. (Though, on the saved login system: this could be kept while removing the form system, as credentials are not being transferred from Bedrock client to Geyser)

Whether Geyser should allow username/passwords after the Microsoft migration is complete is a valid conversation to have - we've seen at least one instance of very likely malicious capturing of usernames and passwords. (Though, should we remove a way to input them, it doesn't stop malicious actors from reintroducing the system; removing them on our end would only help if people were aware of Geyser and aware that we no longer had a username/password system)

My current stance is that the username/password system, while not ideal, is secure enough, excluding the social engineering stance, which I've discussed.

I'm fine with leaving this open for discussion (or make a new issue for it, ideally), but keep it civil and remember the human.

> @25pwn Just because it's insecure does **NOT** mean it should be removed. HTTP (not HTTPS) has been known to be insecure for years, yet web browsers keep support for it.
> 
> For some web pages, such as private ones for your own use or information based pages without any inputs, the extra layer of security is not needed (but recommended, of course).
> 
> In contrast, a Geyser instance you run for yourself or your friends may not _need_ the extra security. It is much more convenient to simply enter your email and password rather than mess about without opening the browser and retrieving a code. While for the most part people _should_ use the Microsoft authentication, we should also think about the people who don't want to or can't for any reason. 

It's true that you might not _need_ the extra security, but it's still bad, let alone not ideal to send a potentially compromised or malicious server your account credentials.
HTTP is not ideal but it's still there for compatibility reasons. But logging in using Microsoft account credentials is a 6-day old feature, and I don't see anyone relying on it yet. Plus like with my friend's case, Microsoft flagged this as malicious and prevented the login, so it won't always work, either. I don't think the luxury of ease of use is valid here; it's very clearly bad in terms of security, and it won't always work in terms of functionality. It's basically inferior in every way.

> Just to add the final touches to this conversation - if you are concerned about the security of username and password, Geyser currently has an option to disable the use of passwords when logging in with online mode. As Mojang accounts still require a password, and our saved logins system uses usernames and passwords, we will not be considering disabling this option globally until at least the migration from Mojang accounts to Microsoft accounts is complete. (Though, on the saved login system: this could be kept while removing the form system, as credentials are not being transferred from Bedrock client to Geyser)
> 
> Whether Geyser should allow username/passwords after the Microsoft migration is complete is a valid conversation to have - we've seen at least one instance of very likely malicious capturing of usernames and passwords. (Though, should we remove a way to input them, it doesn't stop malicious actors from reintroducing the system; removing them on our end would only help if people were aware of Geyser and aware that we no longer had a username/password system)
> 
> My current stance is that the username/password system, while not ideal, is secure enough, excluding the social engineering stance, which I've discussed.
> 
> I'm fine with leaving this open for discussion (or make a new issue for it, ideally), but keep it civil and remember the human.

I am aware of the option to disable it, however it's enabled by default which is a problem imo.

Here are reasons why I believe it should be removed:
- Officially supporting it would familiarize people with the prompt, making it easier for malicious actors to phish credentials out of users.
- It doesn't always work because of security measures put in place by Microsoft, as it may get flagged as a malicious login. Without knowledge about what's actually happening it may degrade the integrity of the server and geyser.
- It's bad for security, since you're transferring account credentials; for the server it introduces an incentive to attack geyser for credentials, and for the end user they are sending their account credentials to a potentially compromised or malicious host.

For now it should at least be disabled by default.

> For now it should at least be disabled by default.

This will be done when MSA is fully migrated as toggling the option also disables username/password auth for Mojang accounts.
We know about the security issues of it being enabled but it's up to you on if you put your login credentials to a random server.

Please go to geyser discord (discord.geysermc.org) and run !!ping in #bot-spam there. After that, go to a support channel and we can answer your question.

I don't mind the "ping", though it's more of a "mention" on GitHub.

1.16.201 is compatible with 1.16.200.

OK I understand that reviving an old PR is not the preferred way to connect to you ;-) I'll ask in discord later because I got really frustrated today trying to connect my phone MC to a Java server using Geyser either standalone or as a plugin. Both failed with the same message and connection was not possible ..

I was just curious if I could figure out the point of code where some kind of version check would happen. All I found was `com.github.CloudburstMC.Protocol:bedrock-v422:d41b84e86c` in `connector/pom.xml` which I also updated. But the built result was not different in outcome.

Version checking happens here: https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/master/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/network/UpstreamPacketHandler.java#L62, and it accepts 1.16.201 fine because its protocol version is 422. If you are getting zero logs from Geyser, then that implies a connection issue where Geyser cannot be reached.

body: The Geyser configuration acts as a global control of if coordinates should even be set to true.

Previously, we wouldn't send the time if the server was sending the same time with doDaylightCycle on. However, this isn't vanilla behavior (for Bedrock nor Java) and can occasionally cause irregularities. The time is now always sent to Bedrock clients, and a daylightCycle field is added to GeyserSession to keep track of the doDaylightCycle gamerule we need to send to Bedrock. Removing the map we used to store the time may also improve memory usage since this was never cleaned up.
commit_messages:
Improve doDaylightCycle translation (#1711)

Previously, we wouldn't send the time if the server was sending the same time with doDaylightCycle on. However, this isn't vanilla behavior (for Bedrock nor Java) and can occasionally cause irregularities. The time is now always sent to Bedrock clients, and a daylightCycle field is added to GeyserSession to keep track of the doDaylightCycle gamerule we need to send to Bedrock. Removing the map we used to store the time may also improve memory usage since this was never cleaned up.

body:
Open Collective is a better choice than Patreon for accepting donations as everything is transparent.

Currently, the fiscal host is set to the Open Source Collective 501(c)(6), which means they control the money. If anyone (including myself) wants to withdraw money we have to submit an invoice (don't worry, its easy and they provide a template) which i can then accept or deny and the Open Source Collective will also have to accept it.

This may sound problematic, but as long as you fill out the fields correctly it is very likely to be accepted by the fiscal host.

**This should be seen as a stop-gap until we get a unified [Open Collaboration](https://github.com/OpenCollaboration) donation method**

---

On the collective page, I currently state the following:
> This collective is run by and for the benefit of the independent contributors to the Geyser open source project. This collective is not endorsed or administered by Digital Tree Media Ltd. All donations made will be expended for the private benefit of or otherwise to reimburse individuals that do not have an employer/employee, contractor, or other agency relationship with Digital Tree Media Ltd.

I am not sure if this is required to use the Open Source Collective, but its what [webpack](https://opencollective.com/webpack) states on their collective. The downside to this message is that @RednedEpic will not be able to receive donations (but it could be worse as he works for CubeCraft). It may be possible to remove the message as it's probably no big deal.
For some reason, the owner UUID metadata was not being sent, but Java still displays the wolf collar correctly.

body: Global palettes don't have their own internal palette, which cannot be iterated through to create a Bedrock palette. Therefore we simply iterate over the whole palette one time. This commit also fixes a regression with flowers/pistons being on multiple chunk sections.
commit_messages:
Fix GlobalPalette translation (#1528)

* Fix GlobalPalette translation

Global palettes don't have their own internal palette, which cannot be iterated through to create a Bedrock palette. Therefore we simply iterate over the whole palette one time. This commit also fixes a regression with flowers/pistons being on multiple chunk sections.

* Don't declare bedrockPalette until after global palette check

body: Merge the spigotlegacycrafting

This PR optimizes the process of translating and encoding chunks for transmission to the Bedrock client.

Profiling and some basic benchmarks suggest a performance boost in the order of 10-20 *times* faster than the current chunk code.

This is nearly done, the only major thing that remains is making partial chunk updates work correctly on Spigot servers (as they don't need a chunk cache, but can serve the block data directly from memory).

body:
Bedrock uses the BLOCK_INTERACT enum of BedrockActionTranslator to truly indicate if a bucket should be used or not. In order to hook into this, we need to delay the bucket placing by about 5 milliseconds - this gives us time to cancel the interaction if needed.

Bucket sounds will now not play in this case as well.
commit_messages:
Fix bucket interactions on creative mode (#1369)

* Fix bucket interactions on creative mode

Bedrock uses the BLOCK_INTERACT enum of BedrockActionTranslator to truly indicate if a bucket should be used or not. In order to hook into this, we need to delay the bucket placing by about 5 milliseconds - this gives us time to cancel the interaction if needed.

Bucket sounds will now not play in this case as well.

body:
This isn't perfect! Feel free to play around and critique the code. I'm no expert in collisions, however; I have to thank `pokechu22` for giving me some excellent reference code to work with.

Unlike fishing rod pulling behavior that is calculated serverside on Bedrock and clientside on Java, Bedrock player "pushing" is nonexistent on Bedrock. This code checks to see if a Geyser player should be moved, and if so applies motion to the player which sends movement packets back.

This commit also cleans up the move relative code of villagers so they aren't always checking the chunk cache.

Fishing rods pulling players is a clientside feature on Java. On Bedrock, a SetEntityMotionPacket is sent to the client. Therefore this PR implements the Java fishing rod pulling mechanics and sends it off to Bedrock, which sends MovePlayerPackets that are sent to the server.
commit_messages:
Add support for fishing rods pulling Bedrock players (#1355)

Fishing rods pulling players is a clientside feature on Java. On Bedrock, a SetEntityMotionPacket is sent to the client. Therefore this PR implements the Java fishing rod pulling mechanics and sends it off to Bedrock, which sends MovePlayerPackets that are sent to the server.

body:
Previously, MCProtocolLib (our Java protocol library) handled keep alive packets for us. This commit disables that option and 'forwards' the keep alive packets to the client, and sending the keep alive packet back once Bedrock sends us a ping response. This allows for a more accurate ping number for servers.

This commit also removes the DataCache class which is no longer used.

Forward keep alive packets to the client (#1344)

Previously, MCProtocolLib (our Java protocol library) handled keep alive packets for us. This commit disables that option and 'forwards' the keep alive packets to the client, and sending the keep alive packet back once Bedrock sends us a ping response.

body: Accidental pullrequest, sorry!

In vanilla Bedrock, if you have operator status, the client can send a packet to change gamemode without confirmation from the server. Since we have a custom server option to request the gamemode, we just reset the gamemode and ignore this packet.
commit_messages:
Prevent Bedrock from changing gamemode client-side (#1337)

In vanilla Bedrock, if you have operator status, the client sends a packet to change gamemode without confirmation from the server. Since we have a custom server option to request the gamemode, we just reset the gamemode and ignore this packet.

body: This commit ensures that the auto-wrapping nature of Bedrock with signs is corrected. If a Bedrock player sends a sign that is auto-wrapped, it will now be interpreted by Geyser to fit on multiple lines. Additionally, Geyser will crop incoming sign text to prevent auto-wrapping.

* Implement correct sign wrapping

This commit ensures that the auto-wrapping nature of Bedrock with signs is corrected. If a Bedrock player sends a sign that is auto-wrapped, it will now be interpreted by Geyser to fit on multiple lines. Additionally, Geyser will crop incoming sign text to prevent auto-wrapping.

* Don't wrap if it's the last line

body:
# Overview

Move around how the login process works to provide a better user experience.

We do this by keeping the "Finding Server" screen up and preloading the downstream connection simultaneously. Only once things are finalized do we then show the world and spawn in all the cached entities.

Supercedes #656

# To Test
* [X] Offline Login
* [x] Online Login with Floodgate

A handful of recipes are complex enough on Java Edition that the client simply calculates them after getting an assurance that they are valid recipes. This PR stores those recipes in a Bedrock-compatible format in mappings, then generates the CraftingData information on startup to send to the Bedrock client when called. This fixes firework rocket and star crafting, and fixes leather armor and shulker box dyeing.

The recipe information for everything except leather armor was taken right from the Bedrock server. The leather armor had to be created separately (see https://github.com/DoctorMacc/LeatherDyeingCreation). There will be a slight visual difference in the crafting result preview if the armor is not perfectly dyed to one of the sixteen colors, but this is a visual issue that will persist unless we calculate every single possbile combination.
commit_messages:
Translate client-computed recipes (#1181)

* Translate client-computed recipes

A handful of recipes are complex enough on Java Edition that the client simply calculates them after getting an assurance that they are valid recipes. This PR stores those recipes in a Bedrock-compatible format in mappings, then generates the CraftingData information on startup to send to the Bedrock client when called. This fixes firework rocket and star crafting, and fixes leather armor and shulker box dyeing.

The recipe information for everything except leather armor was taken right from the Bedrock server. The leather armor had to be created separately (see https://github.com/DoctorMacc/LeatherDyeingCreation). There will be a slight visual difference in the crafting result preview if the armor is not perfectly dyed to one of the sixteen colors, but this is a visual issue that will persist unless we calculate every single possbile combination.

* Revert other changes

* Register shulker box recipes properly

* Add break

* Update mappings

body:
Until 1.16, enchantment tables were impossible to implement properly in Geyser. When a user selects an enchantment in Bedrock, the client creates the book on its end and assumes the server is OK with it. Java requires a button to be pressed to select the enchantment. With 1.16, server authoritative inventories remove that on Bedrock. However, until our inventory rewrite is finished we are still stuck without enchantment table support. This commit serves as an alterative as we wait.

Enchantment table GUI support is still impossible since we are using the pre-1.16 inventory system. To solve this, this commit replaces the enchantment table GUI with a hopper GUI. The first slot serves as the spot you place the weapon. The second slot acts as the lapis slot - Geyser prevents any item from going in there that is not lapis. The final three slots act as the buttons; an enchanted book acts as each button, with the ability to show the translated text of each enchantment.

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/613194828359925800/746164042359504927/unknown.png
commit_messages:
Implement an enchantment table GUI (#1177)

Until 1.16, enchantment tables were impossible to implement properly in Geyser. When a user selects an enchantment in Bedrock, the client creates the book on its end and assumes the server is OK with it. Java requires a button to be pressed to select the enchantment. With 1.16, server authoritative inventories remove that on Bedrock. However, until our inventory rewrite is finished we are still stuck without enchantment table support. This commit serves as an alternative as we wait.

Enchantment table GUI support is still impossible since we are using the pre-1.16 inventory system. To solve this, this commit replaces the enchantment table GUI with a hopper GUI. The first slot serves as the spot you place the weapon. The second slot acts as the lapis slot - Geyser prevents any item from going in there that is not lapis. The final three slots act as the buttons; an enchanted book acts as each button, with the ability to show the translated text of each enchantment.

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/613194828359925800/746164042359504927/unknown.png

body:
This PR is improving the performance of Scoreboards in general and this also fixes timeouts on servers with huge amounts of Scores. It is a combination of multiple improvements, for example it does not longer make new maps/sets on every Scoreboard update.
It now caches the ScoreInfos and batches Score Packets (when there are more then 10 Score Packets per second) to limit how many times we update the Scoreboard.

And I also implemented two thresholds.
The first threshold is on 10 Score Packets Per Second, this will limit the amount of Scoreboard updates to once every second.
The second threshold is on 250 Score Packets Per Second, this will limit the amount of Scoreboard updates to once every 3 seconds.
I'm still not entirely sure about the thresholds, because for example 10 sounds like nothing. But on the other hand the current maximum is 9 updates per second (because when it hits 10, it'll limit the amount of updates to once every second), and that is already quite a lot.

But other then that, everything should still work as intended, but feel free to test it and say what you think about.
commit_messages:
Scoreboard improvements (#1166)

* Added a way to check if debug logging is enabled

* Improved scoreboard performance

* Include Teams in pps and return pending pps instead when higher then pps

Some servers have a huge amount of score packets when the player logs in, but before this commit, only after the first high pps (packets per second) the ScoreboardUpdater will be used (after pending packets per second have been moved to packets per second). But this commit fixes that the ScoreboardUpdater can be used on the second that the pps is getting high.

* Fixed team pre + suffix "null" issue and added threshold config option

Fixed team pre + suffix "null" issue.
When the prefix and/or suffix of a Team is null, "null" will be returned instead of null (Due to the way that MCProtocolLib is made and designed). This is fixed by simply checking if the prefix and/or suffix equal "null" and if that is the case, replace it with "".

Added threshold option.
Gave the person who is running Geyser an option to specify the first Scoreboard packets per second threshold to further improve performance by lowering the setting or decrease performance by relaxing the setting a bit. The value can't be higher then 250 (the second threshold), because it'll always choose the lowest threshold.

* Forgot to bump config version

* Small changes

* Reverted version bump, changed Sponge config, changed FloodgateKeyLoader

Reverted version bump
Camotoy said that you only need to bump the config version if the change is breaking, the config version bump has been reverted.

Changed Sponge config
The Sponge config has been modified to look like the other platform configurations.

Changed FloodgateKeyLoader

* Changed default-locale and (remote) address as requested by Camotoy

* Reduce bandwidth and a few final tweaks

* Made the scoreboard-packet-threshold a bit higher due to improvements

Fix Xbox authentication and add support for proxies (#1162)

Waterdog and ProxyPass will work when `enable-proxy-connections` is set to true at the expense of security.

Sort of a quick edit, perhaps could be cleaner. If you have any comments I'd be glad to edit this more.

I think it could be a useful feature, and this isn't the worst way to do command line arguments if you want to take more arguments in the future -- although maybe it's worth looking at something like Argparse. I didn't use that since I didn't want to add an unnecessary dependency.

Tests:
- [x] Compiles, runs with defaults as expected
- [x] `-h`, `--help` work as expected (print message and exit)
- [x] `-c`, `--config` both work as expected
 - [x] `-c` doesn't crash the program if no config specified
 - [x] `gui` and `nogui` still work as expected.

body:
Adds SplitScreen support by managing multiple GeyserSessions.

Generally fairly happy with code quality, as I think the cleanup of LoginEncryptionUtils is quite nice. Only where I need to reach through Upstream() to get at the BedrockServerSession is a bit meh.

Depends on:
* GeyserMC/Floodgate#50 for using UUID as XUID.
* ~~CloudburstMC/Protocol#65 (quick fix) or CloudburstMC/Protocol#62 (general improvement) for allowing the large WrappedPackets that Switch sends for skinData and skinGeometry.~~ CloudburstMC/Protocol#65 has been merged.

Notes:
* ProxyPass needs to also have the inflate fix if you want to log packets.

This commit supresses the NPE that was previously sent when using an invalid Mojang account. Instead, the Bedrock client is disconnected with an error message.

This PR should not be merged until I update the languages submodule.
commit_messages:
Disconnect client if using an invalid Mojang account (#975)

This commit supresses the NPE that was previously sent when using an invalid Mojang account. Instead, the Bedrock client is disconnected with an error message.

body: This commit now supports immediate respawn if the server enables it - both on the setting being applied on join and the setting being modified in-game. This also refactors the respawning process to more closely match BDS behavior - nothing broke in my testing but more testing is needed.
commit_messages:
Support immediate respawn gamerule (#970)

* Support immediate respawn gamerule

This commit now supports immediate respawn if the server enables it - both on the setting being applied on join and the setting being modified in-game. This also refactors the respawning process to more closely match BDS behavior - nothing broke in my testing but more testing is needed.

* Reuse spawned variable instead of creating new variable

body:
Add an armour command to bypass the clientside restriction on the armour and offhand slots. This may get fixed natively in 1.16 so this will likely be on hold until then.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5401186/84509674-f7887b00-acbb-11ea-91d7-02d00c9b2e3e.png)

Fixes: https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/issues/706

## TODO:
- [x] Add base menu and command
- [x] Allow item moving
- [x] Remove offhand command
- [x] Fix inventory desync
- [x] Bukkit support (see offhand command)

## Changes:
* Implement a transaction based system for resolving inventory changes. A new transaction is created which has all the actions to resolve it, with each action optionally requiring a confirmation step. For example all Click/Drops should only proceed after receiving an associated confirm packet otherwise out of order updates occur. This is also done asynchronously.
* Provide better support for overriding functionality in child inventory translator classes by splitting the steps of resolution out separately.
* Provide better support of refreshing of inventory by using an invalid click and then rejecting the returned packet after syncing the inventory.
* Remove the forced refresh from all translators as they now take care of their updates in an ordered fashion. The only refresh left is now used only when the resolution system knows it may leak items (for example picking up an arbitrary amount from the furnace output is not supported on java).
* Support resolving inventory changes that have more than 2 actions. This may resolve crafting recipes on some platforms and handle large inventory changes better
* If geysers knowledge of an inventory item does not match that of the server and it is rejected we will resync before the retrying the action.
* Added more documentation on whats happening in the inventory resolution.
* Ensure that non click actions are executed at the appropriate location in a transaction through the use of a Runnable

Note that this is a required merge for #536 which will have this merged in already. There are further optimizations that can be done and are in general marked with a TODO (sorry for the ping other todo) once the current resolution system is tested enough.

## Todo
* [x] Optimize resolution by making use of appropriate LEFT clicks or RIGHT clicks to slice a pickup down closer (especially useful for the furnace output slot)
* [X] ~~Someone tests if this fixes crafting for consoles (I don't have one)~~
* [x] Find out if there is any benefit or difference to using a setslot versus inventory packet for updating the cursor.
* [x] Remove some of my debugging ToString annotations I left in by mistake.

## Bugs
* [x] Swapping items between the hotbar and inventory seems to not work. Probably a slot mapping issue.

body:
Still two more issues (Only encountered them in 1.8)

- [ ] Inventory is empty when opening a new trade window. Seems to be because the server sends the `WindowItemsPacket` before the `OpenWindowPacket`...
- [ ] Cannot complete trade. Sleeping the thread for a bit after sending the `SelectTradePacket` appears to fix the problem, but obviously isn't the right solution.
https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/bafe7d430a8b0a555a6167147fcc47310aefd200/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/network/translators/bedrock/BedrockEntityEventTranslator.java#L51-L52

## Overview

This provides a Thread-safe Event Management System for Geyser. A native plugin system is also provided that can utilize the Event system through the use of 3rd party plugin jars.

## Event System

**Please refer to the live documentation for up to date information on how the system has been designed. This section is now outdated**

An event extends `GeyserEvent` or `GeyserCancellableEvent` and can be triggered using the EventManager container on the Connector instance. 

All event handlers will be run in order of priority and handlers can choose to not get cancelled events.

A handler can be defined using a lambda along with the expected event class. 

Example 1:
```java
// Load all this data into memory
myHugeData = readAllTheData();

// We want to save it all when Geyser Shuts down
eventManager.on(DisableEvent.class, (handler, event) -> {
    writeAllTheData(myHugeData);
}).build();
```

Example 2:
```java
// We need to send this second packet only when we get a ResponsePacket
session.sendUpstreamPacket(somePacket);
eventManager.on(BedrockPacketReceiveEvent.class, (handler, event) -> {
    session.sendUpstreamPacket(otherPacket);
    handler.unregister(); // Unregister ourself
  
})
    .filter(ResponsePacket.class)
    .build();
```

Data for an event can be passed in the event object.

Events are triggered by creating a new object that inherits from GeyserEvent and calling the `trigger` method on the Event Manager.

## Plugin System

**Please refer to the live documentation for up to date information on how the system has been designed. This section is now outdated**

A plugin system is also implemented to allow native Geyser Plugins to be written. This will reduce the amount of code that does not belong in the mainline by pulling it out into plugins that can optionally be used. It will also attract a community of developers who may not be interested in dealing with the low level aspects of Geyser but are happy to create useful optional features.

The plugin jar files are placed inside a `plugins` folder relative to the dataFolder of the appropriate bootstrap. This means relative to the jar for standalone and relative to its datafile folder for the other bootstraps. Each plugin can create its own datafolder under there as well.

We make use of a custom classloader that allows a plugin to also specify if it wishes to be part of the global namespace or not (default true). If it is global then other plugins may use its libraries and vice-versa, otherwise it is entirely independent and will not collide with other plugins.

An example plugin which runs on Geyser, Spigot and Bungeecord can be found [here](https://github.com/bundabrg/GeyserLink)

Presently a class annotated with `@Plugin` and extending GeyserPlugin is looked for in the jar and is instantiated, becoming the plugin entrypoint. This annotation also defines all details about the plugin.

All event handlers are annotated by `@Event` and reflection is used to determine which event is hooked. Classes that event handers belong to must be registered with the plugin manager unless it is the main plugin class which is automatically registered.

## Documentation
[Online Documentation](https://bundabrg.github.io/Geyser/)

## Plugins

Please refer to [Awesome Geyser Resources](https://github.com/bundabrg/awesome-geyser-resources) for a list of known plugins so far.

## ToDo
* [x] Proper Documentation
* [x] Plugins should extend from an abstract class to provide helper methods
* [x] Define a list of Events and where they can optimally be hooked into the code.
* [x] Write a better example plugin perhaps one that provides custom filtering on the playerlist as it is easy to understand and by writing it help to know which events are useful.
* [x] Will need #769 merged but we implement the same functionality here anyway for the moment
* [x] Remove edit URL's from the PDF documentation generation
* [x] Remove need for Context in Method Event Handlers
* [x] Individual Packet Events
* [ ] Command to show plugins loaded
* ~~Handle cases where plugins may need to be run on specific platforms (spigot, standalone) by specifying requirements in the plugin annotation.~~ I'm now not so sure this is needed. A plugin writer should test for this using whatever method they wish.
* [x] Implement a delombok step so we can javadoc event fields
* [x] Provide easy method to inject packets to Geyser
* [ ] Provide easy method to register commands not under the Geyser command (https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/issues/1637)

## Events Todo
* [x] PluginMessageEvent + sending messages
* [x] DownStreamPacketReceive
* [x] DownStreamPacketSend
* [x] UpstreamPacketReceive
* [x] UpstreamPacketSend
* [x] GeyserStartupEvent
* [x] GeyserShutdownEvent
* [x] PluginEnableEvent
* [x] PluginDisableEvent
* [x] Ping events

## Optimization
* If no event handlers then we might be able to short circuit some stuff. However as events may be useful to internal geyser code in the future this may quickly become a useless optimization
Thanks to @RednedEpic for laying down the framework of really making this work and @AJ-Ferguson as always for applying his special magic.

This PR will cover all the fixes to the PlayerList that are not directly related to either #656 and #680 whilst I work on them.

## Changes
* When possible make use of the DisplayName sent through a PlayerList instead of its Username. This effectively eliminates dummy entries like "~BTLP12312" which make use of DisplayName to build a fancy tab list.

## ToDo
* [ ] ~~Take care of UPDATE entries~~
* [ ] ~~Add player head images per @rtm516 suggestion~~

Legacy crafting does not work on pre-1.12 servers because no declare recipes packet is sent. On Bukkit, we iterate through all recipes and make a CraftingDataPacket. On other platforms, we infer whenever the output slot is modified.

Currently, non-Bukkit won't let you craft right away but will after you update an item. If we can't fix this I'm fine with merging it since it 'works'.

Fixes #696
This means that for single chests, shulker boxes and hoppers a block doesn't need to be placed above the player's head. Todo:

https://github.com/GeyserMC/mappings-generator/pull/18 needs to be merged first

The same as #669 which was accidentality closed and the branch deleted

Currently fixes #548, #1008 and #617
Might fix #204

**Known bugs that I can only fix when the custom collision boxes are in the release versions**
- Bamboo
- Some grindstone things
- Bugs with snow layers

**Known bugs to fix**

body:
Changes:
* Instead of caching a skin based upon the player we cached it based upon the textureURL. This means multiple players with the same skin will benefit from the cache and more importantly will mean a player changing their skin will not get a false cache hit.
* This should fix all issues with SkinRestorer and will now correctly show the skin both to the player themselves and to other players
* Bedrock seems to cache the skin internally based upon the fullSkinId. Setting this to the textureUrl effectively makes it unique as well.

Video: https://youtu.be/BUpN3y5eQFk

Closes #518

## Still To Do

* [x] Fix playerlist properly. Right now async loading of skins interferes with the regular java playerlist packet and if it comes out of order the wrong skin can get applied or even worse get expelled (from the game by crashing)
* [X] Implement image caching
* [X] Implement image expiring

## Bugs
* [ ] Sometimes when logging in a players own skin is not set. I think it sets correctly then overwrites it with a default due to race issues
* [x] Expiring is not working and will always expire images. 

## Changes
* Minimize Player Updates
* Cache skins based on TextureUrl
* Optional Disk caching of all images
* Memory cache will use timed evictions to eliminate memory leak
* Provide caching for all images (capes, ears)
* Force skins as trusted
commit_messages:
Fix Skin Caching and Fix Skin Restorer (#680)

* Fix Skin Caching

Changes:
* Instead of caching a skin based upon the player we cached it based upon the textureURL. This means multiple players with the same skin will benefit from the cache and more importantly will mean a player changing their skin will not get a false cache hit.
* This should fix all issues with SkinRestorer and will now correctly show the skin both to the player themselves and to other players

Closes #518

* Remove duplicated code

* Minimize playerlist updates

Changes:
* All async skin stuff will now just update skins and not be involved with sending the session to the player. This eliminates issues where the player list changes whilst an async task is occuring plus it means no invisible players while retrieving skin.
* Fix bug when retrieving cached skin

* When sending PlayerList packets ensure the skins have appropriate skinIds so the Bedrock client will cache hit/miss as needed

* Make sure to add and remove player when setting skin if they do not belong on the playerlist

* Make use of AuthData UUID when removing the player

* Revert removal of checking if entity is valid when initialized

This section is supposed to send all spawned entities in the java world to a player only after they've initialized. By removing this check it would also be sending entities that exist but are not spawned.

* Optimizations

Changes:
* Check for duplicate requests based on textureURL instead of player ID
* Don't use the PlayerSkinPacket. It duplicates the data sent in the PlayerListPacket and without it the players still get skin updates.

* Support caching of skins to disk based on configuration variable

If a skin is downloaded it will be saved to `cache/skins` using a base64 encoded filename of the textureUrl, if allowed by setting a non 0 value for the configuration variable `cache-skins`

When reading a skin we try load it from a cache file first before trying to download it.

We don't yet expire them but do update their last modification so we know which ones have been accessed.

* Update `config.yml` with cache-skins directive, defaulting to disabled

* Merge Fixes

* Cache all images instead of just skins

Changes:
* Move the image caching from skins to where images may get downloaded so this also covers capes and anything else that uses the same method of image retrieval
* Updated config value from `cache-skins` to `cache-images`
* Updated cache location from `cache/skins` to `cache/images`
* Images are stored in png format with a uuid. This may make debugging easier as they can be directly opened.

* Implement cached image expiry

If `cache-images` is set to a value greater than 0 then a scheduled task will occur once a day that will remove images with a modification date older than the value in days.

* Force skin changes as trusted

* Resolve PR queries

* Fix signed int causing issues calculating expiry time for images

* Reset Defaults to 0 and implement Google Timed Eviction cache for Images

* Add memory cache for Capes

Co-authored-by: Brendan Grieve <brendan.grieve@zepli.com.au>
Co-authored-by: bundabrg <bundabrg@grieve.com.au>

Adds a basic GUI for standalone that allows for easy command running and only opens if the jar is not started via command-line.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5401186/83275844-a9f21580-a1c7-11ea-9835-9c8b9f3d93d5.png)

Currently fixes #548 (more to come!)
Move fixes V2 using bounding boxes
This has some performance optimisations that could potentially cause problems, now or in the future:
1) It currently only checks block underneath the player by treating the height as 0
2) It doesn't check collision unless the Y position changes
3) It doesn't check collision when onGround isn't set, causing problems when flying into a stair in creative

**Known bugs to fix**
- [x] ~~Sometimes when sprinting up stairs you get teleported back~~ Fixed!
- [ ] Snow layers are a bit buggy (disabling optimisations 2 and 3 at the same time seems to help)
- [ ] Add proper hitboxes for:
- Fences and walls (also with carpets on top)
- Fence gates
- Beds
- Flower pots
- Skulls
- Grindstone

**Todo**

- [ ] Reproduce and fix #204 and https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/issues/682

Please tell me about any more bugs you find!

The downside of this is that config folders will have to be moved, but it should be possible to create a helper class that moves the config.

body:
Bedrock knows its own UUID and when it receives the Java uuid it will either crash (MCEE) or add a ghost duplicate player onto the playerlist (Bedrock).
This change will check if an entity is the client and if so replace the entities UUID with the AuthData UUID.

A refactor of JavaPlayerListEntryTranslator was also done as I got confused each time what it was doing so it is now hopefully a bit clearer and also fixes the case where an entity is removed but still exists on the server (Vanished).
commit_messages:
Use authData UUID when sending playerlist packets to the client (#654)

Bedrock knows its own UUID and when it receives the Java uuid it will either crash (MCEE) or add a ghost player onto the playerlist (Bedrock).
This change will check if an entity is the client and if so replace the entities UUID with the AuthData UUID.

A refactor of JavaPlayerListEntryTranslator was also done as I got confused each time what it was doing so it is now hopefully a bit clearer and also fixes the case where an entity is removed but still exists on the server (Vanished).

body:
## Overview

This provides the following:

  * Developer support for multiple versions in the code. This makes it easier to support multiple editions using common code.
  * Support for Minecraft Education Edition 1.12.60

## Notes

  * This will not compile without first compiling this PR of Protocol which will bring in 2.5.7-SNAPSHOT: https://github.com/NukkitX/Protocol/pull/39
  * `config.yml` is changed to allow you to select the edition of the bedrock listener. If you wish to support multiple versions at the same time you will need to run multiple copies of GeyserMC with different `config.yml` files

## Changes
* Temporarily Disable Github Action as this will not build till https://github.com/NukkitX/Protocol/pull/39 is merged
* Add gamerule "codebuilder":"false" to disable MCEE code builder.
* Update config.yml so that an edition is specified (bedrock or education)
* Move away from automagic annotations to a dependency injection system. This allows versions to use the existing classes or redefine them.
* Implement shims to allow the base codebase to have fewer changes. Any changes to the main codebase will flow into education unless it breaks and requires patching through a shim.
* Move mappings and data resources to be namespaced by the edition (resources/edition)
* Add SkinUtils shim to use legacy geometery data
* Add LoginEncryptUtils shim to add a signedToken for education support. This is managed through a new TokenManager
* Add BlockTranslator shim to handle block mappings with meta values
* Fix respawning in Education as its Packets seem to be slightly different
* Implement a Token Manager to handle OAuth2 tokens with both Microsoft and Minecraft servers. These are saved and updated in `tokens.yml`
* Add new submodule for education mappings.

## Screenshots

Screenshot from MCEE 1.12.16 to 1.15.2 PaperMC server through both ProxyPass and GeyserMC: -

![IMG_20200512_084641](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1607029/81665695-9af32f80-9473-11ea-93f7-86df3906beda.jpg)

## How to host Minecraft Education

The main differences we are interested in between MCEE and MCPE is:
  1. It runs an older slightly modified version of Bedrock.
  2. It has security by only allowing users in the same tenant to connect

Point 2 means that the server must have a valid token for a client to connect otherwise the client will fail with an error indicating that the server is not allowed to be access.

## Generating a new Tenant Token
When a new MCEE tenant needs to be added use the following command:

```
/geyser education new
```

This will provide a URL that must be copy and pasted into your web browser. It starts an OAuth2 authorization flow and allows you to log into your account. Once logged in you will just get a blank page with an address in your address bar. Copy this whole address into the next step.

Now enter the following command:

```
/geyser education confirm {copied response}
```

This will go obtain the token and automatically save to `tokens.yml`.

The same user, and anyone else in the same tenant, can now log into the server. Multiple tenants are supported.

At no time does the server itself ever get access to the password of the user. It only gets access to an OAuth2 token that grants it access to specific minecraft resources and can renew this token indefinitely. If the user changes their password then the OAUTH token will be revoked.

## Example Config

```YAML
bedrock:
  # The IP address that will listen for connections
  address: 0.0.0.0
  # The port that will listen for connections
  port: 19132
  # The MOTD that will be broadcasted to Minecraft: Bedrock Edition clients
  motd1: "GeyserMC"
  motd2: "Another GeyserMC forced host."

  # Edition - bedrock or education
  edition: bedrock

...
```

## Issues

1. ~~Getting the inital token is a little messy. Maybe a better way can be implemented.~~
2. Users logging in with MCEE will have their Tenant username, and if supporting multiple tenants its possible for usernames to collide. Perhaps a prefix based upon the tenant needs to be added to the name or a cache of logged in users and any names that collide get suffixed with a number. If using my bleeding build which includes the plugin PR you may want to use [this plugin](https://github.com/bundabrg/geyserlogin) that allows a player to enter their own username of choice at login.

## Todo
* [x] Move the functionality of the Python token tool directly into Geyser so that it can be initiated with a command. One command will provide a URL that can be pasted into a browser and another command can have the initial token as a parameter.
* [x] Go through mappings and fix obvious mistakes. I have a video here which is of the blocks in all three editions as a comparison: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gK2VGDQBQS0  and a plugin here: https://www.spigotmc.org/resources/debug-scanner.79077
* [ ] After https://github.com/NukkitX/Protocol/pull/39 is merged add back the disabled github action
* [ ] Backport map colors

## Bugs
* [x] Crafting anything does not yet work. 
  * [Working MCEE-MCEE proxypass](https://hastebin.com/raw/zanigovuyi)
  * [Non working MCEE-Geyser proxypass](https://hastebin.com/latiquqejo.cs)
* [ ] Creativing Internal Craft is allowed at the moment when it should show barriers
* [ ] Pressing '/' on desktop MCEE sometimes crashes the client. This may be due to too many commands which can be disabled or perhaps its a bug.

body:
Not sure if this is useful to anyone else but I needed the ability to selectively override block mappings without needing to recompile. In my case it was to convert an end_gateway block to air for my bedrock players which is not something everyone else would want and thus made sense to be a selective override.

This provides the following changes:

* All attempts to load a resource will first look for the path under a "resources" folder relative to the executable and if not found will be retrieved from the internal resource stream. This allows overriding any resource at runtime by creating a file of the same name in "resources/path/to/file".

* When loading mappings/blocks.json we also look for an overrides/blocks.json. Any entry in the override file will override the entry in the mappings file allowing one to selectively override blocks. So in my overrides file (resources/overrides/blocks.json) I just have the entries for the blocks I want to override.

This also adds a proposed fix on some sign overflow. Mainly on characters = and - as those are what I believe to be the most used

Fixes #479 
Fixes #335
