This PR fully brings support for sounds and most all particle effects to Geyser. This PR also contains some more miscellaneous changes, such as the reintroduction of the chunk cache (by default disabled) for full support of these new features and changes.

What this PR does:
- [x] Support for serverside sounds
- [x] Support for particles and effects
- [x] Block and entity interaction sounds (see [SoundInteractionHandler](https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/feature/sounds/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/network/translators/sound/SoundInteractionHandler.java#L38)).
  - [x] Block interaction sounds
  - [x] Entity interaction sounds
- Chunk caching
- Miscellaneous refactors to package structure

Chunk caching was reintroduced to allow for full support for sounds and particles. This feature by default is disabled as it can eat up lots of RAM when there are many players online. In most instances if only one or two people are joining through Geyser at once, RAM should not be eaten up too much. However, having it disabled is not detrimental and only (at this point in time), causes break particles not to show up in creative and sounds not play for blocks with a break time of zero. **However**, if you're running Geyser on a Bukkit server (or any derivative), chunk caching is not used at all as Geyser has direct access to the server itself, so support for these particles are restored.

For those currently running Geyser on a proxy, it is highly advised if you want support for these particles that you migrate over to Geyser-Bukkit, and instead use a proxy supporting Minecraft: Bedrock Edition such as [Waterdog](https://github.com/yesdog/Waterdog).

Though changes in this branch have been tested by many in Discord, this could still benefit from additional testing to help find more recent bugs or any non-mapped sounds that were previously missed.

(Fixes #437)

body:
There were two main issues with the map colors:
The java edition colors were incorrectly interpreted as an signed byte.
The bedrock edition should be encoded as an unsigned int, but were implicitly casted to a long in the NukkitX protocol/network dependency. This is fixed by updating to the newest version of the NukkitX protocol.

Also removed the array stream which wasn't necessary nor made anything any simpler.

body:
Made a few modifications to allow us to map language strings seen in chat from java edition to bedrock edition so we get nicer messages.

Only done a few at the moment, any more string noticed are welcome.

Mappings PR: https://github.com/GeyserMC/mappings/pull/7

Edit:
Working on a new locale conversion using the native Minecraft locale files based on the client's request. https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/pull/270

Bedrock allows spaces but Java Edition does not (or should not). Bad things happen when a user logs in with a space.

This PR simply replaces spaces with _'s. This has the following consequences:

1. Potentially opens a vulnerability for a user with an _ that another user with a space (or vice versa) could log in and be treated as the same user.  I'm not sure if Microsoft already disallow registering a name with an space replaced by an underscore.

2. It may cause other unintended effects so will need testing. One way to test if you don't have a space in your name (because why would you) is to just replace another letter.

It may also be better to move the replacement logic to where MinecraftProtocol is instantiated inside GeyserSession::authenticate so that the replaced username doesn't reach floodgate. 

Closes #263

## ToDo

* [ ] Test that it works with floodgate

- Bedrock players visually see mounting
- Boat rowing animation works on both sides
- Minecarts are 100% done, I believe.

- Proper boat movement from Bedrock to Java

Java Edition includes the bed color in the namespaced ID; in Bedrock edition it's one of the tag values as a block entity. This code involves creating a table between block states and bed color numbers and looking that up on chunk load or block update.

Do note that the color update is not instant when placing a new bed; this is unavoidable in the current code, otherwise the block update will not be received by the client in time.

Fixes #222.

body:
After commit d548647367a3578fa5e7dd6baa3d63bd69006254 I noticed that block placing and breaking no longer worked. After some debugging I found out that sprinting wasn't actually fixed, but the packets were never sent.
This is because the player entity is not being stored in the entity cache, and the null check is always true. https://github.com/GeyserMC/Geyser/blob/d548647367a3578fa5e7dd6baa3d63bd69006254/connector/src/main/java/org/geysermc/connector/network/translators/bedrock/BedrockActionTranslator.java#L45-L49

After some more debugging I found the real cause to the sprinting issue. Whenever the server sent an EntityPropertiesPacket to update the player's movement speed, or an EntityMetadataPacket to update the player's sprinting state, the proxy would send the client a SetEntityDataPacket with the default EntityFlags, causing the client to stop sprinting and desync sneaking. Also, the movement speed attribute modifiers were not being calculated, so the client was reset to the default movement speed.

body:
To make it easier to see which translators have/have not been implemented, as well as to add a bit of structure to the ever-growing list of translators, I refactored the Java packets to follow the package conventions used in MCProtocolLib (source: https://github.com/Steveice10/MCProtocolLib/tree/master/src/main/java/com/github/steveice10/mc/protocol/packet/ingame/server ).

I also removed the redundant "JavaTimeTranslator" (it was replaced with JavaUpdateTimeTranslator but was never removed) and added the "JavaEntityDestroyTranslator" and "JavaSpawnExpOrbTranslator" just to enforce the new package structure (plus, every little packet helps, right? ;))
